name: Daily standups
description: Having a daily standup each day helps us prepare to have the best possible day.

name: Pairing
description: Pairing helps collaboration and knowledge transfer within the team.

name: Team Exploratory Testing Sessions
description: Team exploratory testing helps us gain deep feedback on development work.

name: Lightweight Architecure Decision Records
description: Much documentation can be replaced with highly readable code and tests. In a world of evolutionary architecture, however, it's important to record certain design decisions for the benefit of future team members as well as for external oversight. Lightweight Architecture Decision Records is a technique for capturing important architectural decisions along with their context and consequences. We store these details in source control, instead of a wiki or website, as then they can provide a record that remains in sync with the code itself.

name: Mobbing
description: Mobbing is a software development approach where the whole team works on the same thing, at the same time, in the same space, and at the same computer. The SQL Prompt team are exploring mobbing.

name: Domain-driven Design
description: Domain-driven Design (DDD) is a development approach that deeply values the domain model and connects it to the implementation. DDD gives us the opportunity to keep ourselves honest about striving for persistence ignorance by abstrating the consistency boundaries through proper domain modeling. We are finding it easy to shape the discussions around business language and structure the codebase around the well-established DDD concepts such as Aggregate, Command, Event, etc. There is a also great deal of resource and community support behind this approach which makes it easy to acquire the knowladge. Being explored by The Spiders.

name: C#
description: We build our software using C#.

name: F#
description: F# has some great test and data parsing and manipulating libraries, that are worth exploring as our development becomes more data and api oriented.

name: C++
description: C++ was the right tool for the job in the past.

name: Delphi
description: SQL Backup engine is written in Delphi.

name: VB.Net
description: There is no reason to prefer VB.Net over C#.

name: JavaScript (pre ES6)
description: We don't use older versions of JavaScript. ES6 features like promises, modules and classes significantly improve the JavaScript experience, and tools like BabelJS allow us to adopt this with confidence.

name: JavaScript (ES6+)
description: We use JavaScript for rapid prototyping of ideas because it allows us to go faster. In code bases where we already have significant JavaScript we will continue to use modern JavaScript.

name: TypeScript
description: TypeScript provides an advanced type system on top of JavaScript. We have a preference for TypeScript in production code because the optional type safety can help and improved tool support.

name: Autofac
description: Autofac is an Inversion of Control container for .NET Core, ASP.NET Core, .NET 4.5.1+ and our preferred IoC container choice. Autofac allows you to register components and express dependencies through its flexible module system and simple extension points.

name: Ninject
description: Ninject is a dependency injector for .NET applications. However, Autofac is our preferred IoC container.

name: NUnit 2
description: NUnit is our default framework for writing unit and integration tests. NUnit 2 is working well in most projects that use it, but consider upgrading to NUnit 3 for newer features.

name: NUnit 3
description: NUnit is our default framework for writing unit and integration tests. We use NUnit 3 by default for new projects.

name: Pester
description: Pester is our default framework for writing tests in PowerShell. We use Pester by default for new PowerShell tests.

name: Balsamiq
description: Balsamiq gives us the ability to create quick low-fidelity wireframes to describe workflows.

name: Git
description: Git is our defacto VCS, and all repositories are stored on GitHub.

name: OneDrive
description: OneDrive is our default choice for storing Office documents to share within the organization. In the last three years, Microsoft have done a lot of work on OneDrive and the associated sync clients and have closed the gap on their competitors. The sync client is very stable and doesn’t contain the restrictions that it did before.

name: Raygun
description: Raygun allows loosely-coupled error reporting to a web endpoint. Currently being explored with SQL Prompt, SQL Clone and SQL Monitor.

name: Google Drive
description: We don’t have corporate Google accounts and it doesn’t make sense to subscribe to both GSuite and Office 365, both for cost reasons and from an information management point of view. The fact that we don’t have corporate accounts means data can’t be removed from Google accounts when someone leaves the company (as we don’t own the account), so we shouldn’t be storing any personal information (such as customer data) in Google Drive.

name: SmartAssembly
description: SmartAssembly obfuscation, error and usage reporting becomes tightly-coupled to products and slows down builds.

name: Windows 7+/2008R2+
description: Our default supported operating system is Windows. If Microsoft continues to support this as part of their default support package we continue to support running our applications on that OS. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/13853/windows-lifecycle-fact-sheet

name: Chrome
description: Chrome is Google's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: Firefox
description: Firefox is Mozilla's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: Edge
description: Edge is Microsoft's evergreen browser. We support it by default.

name: IE 11
description: IE 11 is the default browser on Windows 10 and makes up approximately 10% of the visits to Redgate.com. We support it by default.

name: IE 10 and under
description: We do not support IE10 and under.

name: Raven DB
description: We previously used Raven DB in DLM Dashboard but our experience was not positive.

name: NSubsitute
description: NSubstitute is our default mocking library of choice. We feel it's got less setup cost than Moq and requires fewer .Object calls.

name: Moq
description: Moq is a great framework for mocking, but we prefer NSubstitute's simplicity. We see no benefit in having a common mocking framework across solutions.

name: Fakes
description: We've experimented using Fakes in the Redgate Usage Client - fakes used in the test can reduce the amount of mocking is required and can make the tests simpler.

name: Rhino Mocks
description: Rhino Mocks is no longer actively maintained, nor does it support .NET Core / .NET Standard.

name: Wix 3
description: Windows Installer XML Toolset 3 (WiX), is a free software toolset that builds Windows Installer packages from XML. We default to Wix v3.

name: Wix 2
description: Windows Installer XML Toolset 2 (WiX), is a free software toolset that builds Windows Installer packages from XML. We default to Wix v3.

name: Inno Setup
description: SQL Backup uses divergent installer technology.

name: RedGate.Usage.Client
description: Redgate's standard tool for Product and Feature usage reporting.

name: AppInsights
description: Microsoft's platform for data analysis.

name: MixPanel
description: Tool for presenting analytic data. Now superseded by AppInsights. We will review whether to retire this when Application Insights has a configurable retention period.

name: Google Analytics
description: Tool for presenting analytic data. Now superseded by AppInsights.

name: SonarQube
description: Sonarqube provides automated code review, highlighting quality issues in changing code. This feedback is best surfaced through automated PR comments.

name: RedGate.Build
description: Redgate's standardised, scripted infrastructure for building products. Based on build-script-templates.

name: Custom build scripts
description: Builds scripts that diverge from RedGate.Build. These were useful when first made, but we should move to sandard RedGate.Build when possible.

name: Build magic
description: Legacy build tooling, now to be deprecated in favour of RedGate.Build.

name: IL weaving
description: Byte weaving magic is not desirable as it adds compile time complexity that is often not visible to developers. Please note that this does not incorporate static linker tools such as ILMerge as they can still be useful to make some components more reusable by internalising a subset of their dependencies.

name: Fody
description: Tool for IL weaving. No longer endorsed.

name: Vagrant
description: Vagrant is an open-source software product for building and maintaining portable virtual software development environments. We use Vagrant with Puppet to provision test environments and internal infrastructure.

name: Puppet
description: Puppet is an open-source software configuration management tool. We use Vagrant with Puppet to provision test environments and internal infrastructure.

name: DevCloud
description: DevCloud is an internal platform for hosting short-lived virtual machines.

name: Long-lived Virtual Machines
description: We avoid using long-lived virtual machines, especially those that cannotbe trivially rebuilt on demand.

name: Docker
description: Docker is a tool designed to make it easier to create, deploy, and run applications by using containers. Current being explored by Whitesharks.

name: Kubernetes
description: Kubernetes is an open-source container-orchestration system for automating deployment, scaling and management of containerized applications. Currently being explored by Whitesharks.

name: Lucidchart
description: Diagramming tool that allows drawing architectural diagrams in a team environment. Also allows integration with OneDrive, Confluence, etc. Currently being explored by The Spiders team.

name: draw.io
description: Simple Open source diagramming tool that allows drawing architectural diagrams. Also allows integration with OneDrive, Jira, Confluence, etc. Currently being explored by the Prompt team (for C4 diagrams).

name: CEF
description: Chromium Embedded framework (CEF) is an open source framework for embedding a web browser engine inside other tools. This was explored, but proved unsuccessful for Redgate.

name: Winforms
description: Winforms is a legacy UI library in the .NET Framework. Maybe Redgate products already use Winforms, but we prefer other tools for new development.

name: WPF
description: Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) s a graphical subsystem provided with the .NET Framework. It's one of our prefered desktop UI technologies, especially when embedding products inside Visual Studio or SSMS.

name: Electron
description: Electron is an open-source desktop UI framework. It's developed/maintained by GitHub, and used by Microsoft for VS Code. It's one of our prefered desktop UI technologies, especially for standalone desktop tools.

name: Check for Updates (CfU)
description: Redgate's established mechanism for distributing product upgrades. The update process is manual and intrusive for users, leading to slow version uptake and version fragmentation in production. We're keen to explore alternatives.

name: User-controlled background updates
description: Allowing a user to kick off a background upgrade of products, from the UI. Being explored by ICloneable<Sheep> on SQL Clone.

name: Log4Net
description: Log4Net is no longer actively maintained. We've also had problems with our use of it by having a single static root. We don't recommend this for new applications, but can tolerate existing usages.

name: SeriLog
description: Serilog is our preferred logging framework. It's well maintained, supports structured event data and is portable between .NET platforms.

name: Oracle database
description: Oracle database is a strong rival to SQL Server. Redgate has legacy tools for this suite (Oracle Compare & Source Control), and the space is under ongoing investigation by Foundry (with support from TKomp).

name: SQL Server on Linux
description: SQL Server has had growing support on Linux for some time, but Linux is not a platform that Redgate actively targets. Current windows-based tools support connecting to a SSoL database, and further value is being explored in Foundry.

name: Azure DB Studio
description: Azure DB Studio is Microsoft's aspirational replacement for SSMS. Potential Redgate tooling support is being investigated by Foundry.

name: SQL Change Automation
description: Redgate SQL Change Automation is our commerical offering to help people manage the state of databases as part of application deployment. We should investigate if/how to use our own tools as part of our development activities. Versioning Teams to investigate this by looking at how CORE manage databases.

name: React
description: React is our web framework of choice. It's popular, it's easy to understand and it's got great tooling support.

name: Honeycomb Web Toolkit
description: Honeycomb is our design system and the web toolkit makes adopting this in your own projects easy.

name: SignalR
description: SignalR allows server code to send asynchronous notifications to client-side web applications.

name: Webpack
description: Webpack is a module bundler. It's main purpose is to bundle JavaScript files for usage in a browser.

name: Babel
description: Babel is a JavaScript compiler allowing you to confidently use the latest JavaScript features in all browsers.

name: Enzyme
description: Enzyme is a JavaScript Testing utility for React that makes it easier to assert, manipulate and traverse your React Components' output.

name: Redux
description: Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps. We recommend this when state management becomes complicated with React alone.

name: Knockout.js
description: Knockout is a minimilast library for binding data to web views. We prefer React now though existing usages of knockout.js are fine.

name: JQuery
description: JQuery has had it's time. Modern browsers and advances in JavaScript means we don't require it any more.

name: Manual releases
description: A release that involves someone manually going through a whole heap of steps across different systems is bad.

name: Release scripts
description: Using a single powershell script (basic-release.ps1 or using RG.Release) to manage your entire release process is a good trade off between saving effort, and security and accountability for each release.

name: Automated releases via Octopus Deploy
description: Octopus is more trustworthy than TeamCity for automating releases (via @rmc47), so teams wishing to try this should first move their release process to Octopus. SQL Monitor currently uses Octopus for deploying to monitor.red-gate.com.

name: Trello
description: Some teams use Trello for issue management and digital taskboards. Setup and administration are cheap, but issue management capabilities are limited.

name: Jira
description: Some teams use Jira for issue management and digital taskboards. The setup and administration costs are higher than other tools, but issue management capabilities are rich.

name: GitHub Issues
description: Some teams use GitHub issues for issue management and digital taskboards. Setup and administration are slightly costlier than Trello, while issue management capabilties are limited. Integration with source code and repositories can be valuable, but is also complex for multi-repository projects.

name: Physical whiteboards
description: Some teams use physical whiteboards for issue management and a physical taskboard. Costs are variable dependent on the setup and how the tool is used but can be minimal. Issue management and audit capabiltiies are minimal.

name: .NET Framework 4.6.1
description: We continue to build our products using the .Net framework, but libraries should target .Net Standard.

name: .NET Framework 4.7.1
description: A newer version of .NET Framework, which supports .NET Standard better than previous versions. Currently being explored by the Masketeers in Figleaf.

name: .NET Standard 2.0
description: Microsoft has delivered a cross-platform future. New applications should be built to conform to .NET Standard by default.

name: .NET Core 2.0
description: Microsoft has delivered a cross-platform future. New applications should be built with .NET Core by default whenever possible. .NET Core doesn't yet support WPF/Winforms applications, but we're hopeful for support in .NET Core 3.

name: SSMS 2012 and above
description: SQL Server Management Studio 2012 and above are supported my Microsoft, so we should support them in our tools.

name: SQL Server 2008 and above
description: SQL Server 2008 and above are supported by Microsoft, so we should support them in our tools.

name: Chocolately
description: Windows Package Manager

name: Our Own Tools
description: Eat our own dogfood

name: Single Click Release/Deploy
description: Manual decision, Automated pipeline process

name: Adherence to SOLID
description: Good solid development principles

name: Making Work Visible
description: Expose work in progress

name: Impact Mapping
description: Ties strategy and goals to what we do day to day

name: Tech Radar
description: This. How meta.

name: RESTful APIs
description: Decouple all the things.

name: Sketch Noting
description: Visual learning
